detaileddescription.para: Allocates space for the list structure clearing the head and tail pointer ready for use.

simplesect.para: provides a pointer to the newly created list

briefdescription.para: adds a node to a list

detaileddescription.para: allocates space for a new node and places the node at the end of the list

parameterdescription.para: the list to add the node to
the data that this node points to

briefdescription.para: inserts a node at any point in the list

detaileddescription.para: The newly created node takes the position of the inserted node, with the insert node and all subsequent nodes coming after it in the list order

parameterdescription.para: the list you want to insert the node into
the node in the list at the position you want to insert the new node at
the data new node points to

simplesect.para: the newly created node is returned

briefdescription.para: search for a node in the list

detaileddescription.para: brute force search for a node pointing to specific data generally you should be iterating lists and not dealing with specific nodes individually but this could come in handy

parameterdescription.para: the list you want to find the node in
finds the node that points to this data

simplesect.para: checks each node in turn looking for a node that points to ptr returns NULL if it doesn't find a match

detaileddescription.para: this unlinks the node from the list and then frees its memory (the user is responsible for the data the nodes data pointer points to) the pointer to the node (pnode) is then NULLed to aid bug and resource checking

parameterdescription.para: the list containing the node you wish to delete
a pointer to the node pointer you want to delete, the node pointer is returned NULLed

detaileddescription.para: this unlinks the node from the list and then frees its memory (the user is responsible for the data the nodes data pointer points to) the pointer to the node (pnode) is then NULLed to aid bug and resource checking the node is found by searching for a node with a matching data pointer

parameterdescription.para: the list containing the node you wish to delete
a pointer to data, for selecting the node

detaileddescription.para: this will iterate the list freeing all the nodes in it. The list is still valid for use afterwards

parameterdescription.para: the list you want emptying

briefdescription.para: free a list and all its resources

detaileddescription.para: this empties and frees all resources used by the list. Once freed it cannot be used... This does not free what a node is pointing to just the nodes data structure.

parameterdescription.para: The address of the list pointer. It will be freed and then set to NULL to aid bug & resource checking.

detaileddescription.para: This moves forward through a list calling a callback function for each node in the list. If a callback is not apropriate, because for example you need to access local variables then you should iterate the list in this manner

parameterdescription.para: the list to iterate
the callback should return nothing and take only a node pointer as its parameter

detaileddescription.para: identical to clistIterateForwards execept in direction

parameterdescription.para: the list to iterate
the callback should return nothing and take only a node pointer as its parameter

detaileddescription.para: does a simple bubble sort on a list depending on node compare callback

parameterdescription.para: the list to iterate
the callback which should return 1 if n1 > n2

detaileddescription.para: This iterrates the list counting all the nodes

parameterdescription.para: the list you wish to total

simplesect.para: [out] the number of nodes in the list

detaileddescription.para: test to see if the list is empty

simplesect.para: 1 if empty, 0 if at least 1 node
